Pre-Game Insights: England will use the T20 series to gauge their World Cup readiness.
England were initially scheduled to tour Pakistan last year but it did not materialise because of security concerns.
Jos Buttler's men were only given the green light to tour this year after a security team evaluated the situation on the ground.
England will play four matches in Karachi and three in Lahore before returning in December to play three tests in the second leg of the tour.
Moeen Ali will lead the side in the Karachi leg as Jos Buttler recovers from a knee injury.
The tour is crucial for cricket and also for England as a side.
Seven T20s will be a stern test in these conditions and a good pointer for where they are, ahead of the World Cup in Australia next month.
England last toured Pakistan in 2005 but at least 10 members of the current squad have some experience of local conditions courtesy of their Pakistan Super League (PSL) stints.
Pakistan will look to shrug off the disappointment of losing to Sri Lanka in the Asia Cup final earlier this month.
Pakistan will look to iron out the kinks in their batting approach in 20-overs cricket during the series.
England begin their Twenty20 World Cup campaign against Afghanistan in Perth on Oct. 22, a day before Pakistan’s opener against arch-rivals India in Melbourne.
Miscellaneous Highlights: Rickelton’s marathon 259, Verreynne century thumps hapless Pakistan
Alex Hales will be particularly keen to impress after his three-year absence from international cricket due to an off-field issue.
Skipper Babar Azam’s slump in form, and their overall batting approach in 20-overs cricket, have been major talking points for Pakistan.
